answers.author: Shelley Cason
answers.text:
We are currently working toward a value based benefit program in Florida. It is in the peliminary stages currently, but if the program is approved employees for the first year will earn a 2.5% discount on their premium for participating in a personal health assessment. The folllowing year what we plan to implement is a variety of activities, for example 50 different activities lunch n learns,screenings,  that employees can participate in to earn points. If the employee earns 25 points throughout the year then they will receive a discount for participating in wellness activities.  If you are interested I will keep you posted. Our Wellness program this past year has flourished, we have been very blessed to actually get a position for a Health & Wellness Coordinator, before the position became available our Wellness team ran on designated employees throughout many Departments. The team has been success, we have held a Wellness Fair for the past two year with approximately 300 participates and approximately 60 different types of health and wellness vendors.

answers.author: Christine Thompson
answers.text:
Sharonville, Ohio is proposing programs as you describe for the first time next year.  I am proposing a 5% premium difference between tobacco and non-tobacco users.  I am also proposing that employees meet a specific goal per quarter in order to receive their HSA contribution from the city.  Those activities would include a biometric screening, an annual physical, completion of a health risk assessment and completion of a specific wellness topic coaching.  This year we did a similar program that earned points toward HSA funding.  I see a premium difference for obesity in the next 5 years.

author: Bonnie Svrcek
text: In an effort to contain health insurance premiums and support employee wellness/workplace productivity, we are searching for examples of organizations that have implemented a wellness compliance model. Many organizations require employees to participate in health risk assessments and may require those employees who refuse to participate to pay more towards their health insurance.  Is anyone requiring employees to comply with the outcome of a health risk assessment?  For example, if an employee smokes does he/she have to contribute more to their health insurance; or if a person is obese, are they required to pay more towards their health insurance?
title: Wellness Compliance Programs
